div.p: S. I received your letters, most esteemed lord, and I give you my greatest thanks. I know that we have nothing certain, except that it is written to me from Innsbruck and affirmed by Mr. Vogler that a Jesuit of great renown, a court preacher, has been converted to the truth by the learned reading of your Apocalypse and now openly and publicly declaims against idolatry, neither fearing dangers nor future plots; yet, so that he is not removed from the office and duty of public preaching, he still proceeds cautiously; the Spanish Inquisition is also secretly exercised and confirmed in those places; Maximilian, the archduke, has also been urged by letters not to change anything in religion; he himself is displeased, etc. - It is said that the greatest burdens of papal money have been brought to our legate, but have been carried away elsewhere from the fortress. - It is also written from Innsbruck that the royal army has been destroyed by the Huguenots. So much for this. I could barely steal away these few things; so many things trouble me.
Farewell, most excellent and most merciful man and father. May the Lord always keep you.
Quickly from our court, December 7, 1568. Your most devoted Tobias Egli.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his most esteemed lord.
Zurich, at the pastor of the Great Minster.
